text: After delete + restore, the workflow state is still "trash".
creator: andreas@apache.org

text: That's weird, it seems to occur only with Tomcat ...
creator: andreas@apache.org
andreas@apache.org
text:
<element key="workflowVersion">
<value>0 event:delete state:trash user:lenya machine:127.0.0.1
date:2007-02-15_19:13:07 var:is_live=false</value>
<value>1 event:restore state:authoring user:lenya machine:127.0.0.1
date:2007-02-15_19:15:30 var:is_live=false</value>
<value>2 event:delete state:trash user:lenya machine:127.0.0.1
date:2007-02-15_19:18:21 var:is_live=false</value>
</element>

creator: andreas@apache.org
text: Strange, I can't reproduce it anymore.

creator: rfrovarp@apache.org
text:
I was able to replicate it on zones. It does seem to be Tomcat only, as I can't
reproduce on my Jetty builds and I don't have a Tomcat build to test against. To
replicate it on zones, I had to do it a few times. I think it was archive,
restore, delete, restore, delete, problem. It put its workflow to trash, but
kept it in the authoring tree. From there you can't do anything.

creator: andreas@apache.org
text: The zone runs Jetty, so it seems to occur on both servers.

I think I found it - the area names were lazy-loaded and not refreshed, so the
archive version meta data were not set. I changed getAreaNames() and can't
reproduce the problem anymore.

If it occurs again - please reopen.
creator: andreas@apache.org
